Silver and its salts have had a long history of use as antiseptics and disinfectants, and their broad‐spectrum biocidal properties are well established.
181 Silver dihydrogen citrate, for instance, can reduce the infectivity of feline calicivirus, a surrogate for the human norovirus (which causes diarrhea and vomiting), by > 4 log 10 units after 1 and 30 min in suspension and on glass surfaces, respectively.
182 Silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) are a class of silver nanomaterials and are defined as dispersions of silver particles between 10 and 100 nm in size. Generally, AgNPs are effective biocides in small doses,
183 although their potential toxicities to humans are still under intense debate.

185 Modern methods have enabled AgNPs of well‐defined shapes, particle sizes, and polydispersity to be synthesized,
186 which are important parameters that dictate their eventual biocidal activities, biological fate and toxicity.
